 Did BofA Really Beat the Street?
 
 
Though it looks like BofA's reported earnings of 72 cents a share on revenue of $20.6 bn beat analysts estimates of 53 cents a share on sales of $18.4 bn, the results do not include the colossal losses at Countrywide. BofA (BAC: 30.19, +2.70, +9.82%) won shareholder approval to acquire Countrywide for $2.5 bn on July 1. 

 
 
But those profit results do not include Countrywide's massive losses. BofA did report Countrywide's results separately in its earnings release.
 
 Factor in Countrywide's $2.33 bn in losses, and BofA's profit plunges to $1.1 bn, more than a fifth of the year earlier period, missing analysts estimates by a country mile (according to my read of it, some cow-eyed analysts' estimates had factored in the CFC acquisition).

 
 First, Steeeve, how in the hell did they justify reporting countrywide losses completely separately? Is this one of those "letter of the law" things? If so, we need to change the law, add something like "ensure that results are clear and unambiguous to the public" to auditors responsibility because frankly this is BS. 
 
 I read the earnings report when it came out and it was like "Everything is looking pretty good, earnings are down but life is still pretty sweet" then they toss in "oh, and we lost another 2 billion on countrywide".

Are these people on freaking crack?? Over half the corporate bankruptcies this year are companies CEASING OPERATIONS. Who does an audit firm work for? The answer, is now, the company as opposed to the stockholders. Now, this doesn't mean the auditor can ignore GAAP but it does mean they can ignore what might be a questionable practice and accept an accounting practice so long as it technically goes with the letter of the law. Remember those SIV's that Citi had? Off the balance sheet and all of a sudden they had to bail them out...we discussed long before that ever happened that they were a risk to Citi and Citi was 100% responsible for them. So when they are barely a footnote on the financials who is that really serving? Technically it was correct but to anyone with a brain it obviously should have been reported on the balance sheet for people to see because it created a more likely than not threat to the company. Now if KPMG had said "hey, you should really put those on the balance sheet" then Citi would have said "it isn't against GAAP" and would have switched auditors if forced causing KPMG to lose a huge client.
